author: @lowtech42
text:
Few observations:
- FD really was on here sounding like an old Jerry Springer episode üòÇ
- There was a point where (I forget the time code) Olay mentioned the biased ways Shannon et al. were "framing" the convos around Angel/Caitlyn. I just wanted to add that the innate purpose of frames is to create limits and boundaries around the full picture. Societal narratives will never encapsulate the full truth, but instead use the stories to manufacture consent and as justification for further exploitation/oppression. 
- Sports is the battleground for society's identity issues to play out.
- This discourse as it relates to Shannon & the talking heads (sounds like a band name üòÇ) and the idea of Black athletes having to adhere to Black stereotypes for capitalistic success was covered in James Baldwin's essay "The Price of the Ticket". I'm always gonna advocate for people to read more Baldwin! 
- Love as always to Olay + friends üíú This one hit close to home because my cousin plays in the WNBA

author: @kilimanjaro5537
text:
My personal take is:

I agree, I hadn‚Äôt heard of Caitlyn Clark until LSU won the championship. And some white people showed their butts as usual because they were upset that a Black girl had the audacity to win and then rub it in their face. Do I think Angel could‚Äôve just took her win without the pettiness, yes. HOWEVER, she‚Äôs her own person and that‚Äôs all I can say. I will say though that I believe similarly to Taylor Swift, Caitlyn Clark is their LAST great white hope and I say ‚Äúlast‚Äù because the tides are shifting and white people are having some sort of panic because they recognize that they are not the future of this country, let alone the world. 

I also think Angel responds the way she does in interviews because of this and she‚Äôs frustrated. Now does this take away from Caitlyn being a good player, no. However, I will mention she played against my university and I personally was not seeing all the hype but my school‚Äôs women‚Äôs bb team is really good so yeah. But this doesn‚Äôt change the fact that she is being used by racist white people to push their agenda. I‚Äôm sure she is bringing in ticket sales but even that I believe has a large part to do with the fact that these people aren‚Äôt genuinely supporting women‚Äôs sports but coming from a place of hate and wanting to see a white girl beat black women. 

The support isn‚Äôt genuine, and I‚Äôm pretty sure if Angel wouldn‚Äôt have done that John cena wave, we would‚Äôve never heard about Caitlyn Clark again because they wouldn‚Äôt have felt a need to protect her. They‚Äôre only rooting for her so hard because they perceive Angel as an enemy. You remove the supposed enemy and you lose the passion. Some people only care about something if they feel like there‚Äôs an enemy to beat.

author: @JDBaldBabyVance
text: This video gave me a lot to think about. I've been thinking about looking into sports to have something to talk to with people and get interested in something new, but a lot of the male dominated sports usually have detestable people running and dominating in them such that I didn't really want to support any of them. With the whole recent Caitlin Clark buzz, I'd been thinking about watching and supporting my nearest WNBA team. I hadn't considered how much it comes across like WNBA mattering now that it has a white face. replies.author: @antoniosamuel922
replies.text: @brandond1947 Points and shooting aren‚Äôt the same. James Harden and Kobe are good scorers. Steph is a good shooter. The WNBA 3 point average last year was 34.7%. I know tv shows the makes and the narrative that she‚Äôs the female Steph Curry so people say she‚Äôs the best ever but the numbers don‚Äôt show. Last year in college she ranked 55th in 3pt percentage. Sure there‚Äôs some context as I‚Äôm not disingenuous enough to act like someone that only shot 4 threes all season and made 2 is a better shooter than CC since they shoot 50 percent. But once you start getting past 100-150 threes we have a good feel for how well you shoot. Pao Pao from SC was a waaaaay better shooter than CC. She didn‚Äôt shoot as many. I‚Äôll say she‚Äôs a solid shooter being fair. I won‚Äôt call her average that‚Äôs a bit of an exaggeration. But calling her Steph Curry is a larger exaggeration. The year he led the league in 3 point attempts and the highest in his career was also his highest 3 point percentage in his career. At like 45%.

replies.text: @brandond1947 Agreed she‚Äôs a rookie. That‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt mean she‚Äôll get better. She might stay the same. Might get worst. You can‚Äôt assume that based on no facts. I‚Äôm just going by what is and since you‚Äôre already saying she‚Äôs a great shooter I‚Äôm arguing that point. She‚Äôs not. You also made a disingenuous point about Pao Pao matching my example of someone shooting 4 threes all season. She averaged 5 and and 5.5 3‚Äôs per game her last two seasons and shot 42 and 46% from 3. That about 200 threes. The season CC shot the least 3‚Äôs she had the worst 3 point percentage. author: @intellectualnapalm
text:
There have been Caitlyn‚Äôs before.  White guards who were picked first.  Sue Bird, Diana Taurasi , Kelsey Plum, Sabrina Ionescu.  

All of these players were considered (skill for skill) all around better players coming out of college.  

Jason Whitlock would claim she‚Äôs not part of the ‚ÄúAlphabet gang‚Ä¶‚Äù. Neither is Plum.  I don‚Äôt know about Sabrina‚Ä¶. And plum is CLEARLY better looking.  In fact all are arguably better looking, including Diana and she doesn‚Äôt even present as feminine.  This statement was just in reference to marketability.  

So why is Caitlin being hoisted?

It‚Äôs not because she broke the scoring record in college.  Because she broke Plum‚Äôs record.  So Plum would have been hoisted.  Truth is, She is the only one of these 5 women who had the one thing white people rally around  more than all other things combined:  a black foil.  Angel Reese is more important to this narrative than Caitlin Clark.  If Bird, Taurasi, Plum, or Ionescu had a black foil, this response from the collective yt community would have happened then.  

Without Reese, CC would be no different than those other 4.  Her long range shooting is NOT the thing selling out arenas.  It‚Äôs a thing, but it‚Äôs not the thing.

None of the other 4 were tasked with saving the collective white sports soul of America.

Serena and Venus' dad told us a long time ago about his plan to get his daughters paid and be very effective as their manager.  He raised CHAMPIONS with a desire to win. Even tennis Champs like Chris Everett constantly criticized 1about them, training, technique, limited play, education, business choices, interviews and so many other criticisms. physical abuse.  Catelyn is a talented athlete who ended on the wrong team because of the draft.  Being #1 doesn't mean much in the WNBA and definitely not as much as the NBA.
